page.title: 05Farming in Thurlow
page.content: The land, part of a 13000 acre estate formed originally by the buying up of small farms is farmed 'in hand' by the owner and his estate manager, farm manager and stockman, who all live in this block. Shelter belts of evergreen and deciduous trees planted since 1940 provide timber which is felled in rotation with saplings replanted among existing trees, or clear felled and completely replanted. Thinnings are used for pulp wood, or rails and posts on the estate, and big timber is sold commercially. The land, lowland clays, chalks and sandstones is very heavy and once winter sets in becomes impossible to work, so timeliness is of the essence. This means that each summer and autumn harvesting must be finished promptly, a problem in a wet summer, and the land ploughed and harrowed in time to drill the seeds.
